awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Fostering conceptual understanding and skill with an intelligent tutoring system for equation solving
awd_abstract_narration:
This Education and Human Resources Core Research project addresses a persistent challenge in designing effective mathematics instruction: how to foster deep learning of concepts and skills, with strong connections among them. This challenge arises especially in middle school and high school algebra; far too often, students in algebra courses come away with only a moderate level of skill at procedures (e.g., equation solving) with almost no conceptual understanding of why these procedures work. This lack of deep understanding is unfortunate, because algebra is an important stepping stone to advanced mathematics as well as to future educational and employment opportunities. Thus, there is a great need for algebra instruction that helps students acquire well-integrated knowledge of key concepts and problem-solving procedures. This project tackles this issue using, as a platform, a software-based intelligent tutoring system that will extend an existing tutoring system for algebra. The new, enhanced tutoring system will support both practice in solving equations and new conceptually-oriented algebra activities. It will provide detailed and targeted guidance that adapts to individual students' errors, strategies, and developing algebra knowledge. Lab-based and classroom studies will investigate three key questions: (1) What mix of conceptual and procedural activities best helps students acquire deep skill and conceptual knowledge of algebra? (2) How frequently should students shift back and forth between the two types of activities? (3) How effective is the new tutoring system compared to commonly-used software, namely, Khan Academy, or a standard intelligent tutoring system that provides procedural practice only? The project will lead to new knowledge about how to create effective instruction for middle school and high school algebra, together with new intelligent tutoring software that embodies this knowledge.

Based on past research, it is commonly accepted that in many domains, gains in conceptual knowledge can lead to gains in procedural knowledge, and vice versa. Further, there is some evidence that instruction that shifts back and forth between conceptually-oriented activities and procedurally-oriented activities is especially effective. However, it is not yet known what sorts of activities best support the development of conceptual knowledge, or how they should be integrated with activities that target learning of procedures so that students might make connections between the two. To address these issues, the project will extend existing tutoring system for equation solving (called Lynnette) with conceptual activities, based on past research that suggests that worked examples, self-explanation, visual representations (namely, bar diagrams), and activation of prior knowledge can be effective for promoting gains in conceptual knowledge. In doing so, this will leverage an established technical infrastructure for intelligent tutoring systems research and development, called CTAT/Tutorshop. The project will conduct two lab studies and two classroom studies to investigate what mix of conceptually-oriented activities is the most effective complement to the system's current set of procedurally-oriented activities, how frequently students should shift back and forth between procedurally- and conceptually-oriented activities, and how effective the resulting tutoring system is, compared to two control conditions in which students work with commonly used types of software for algebra learning (Khan Academy and Lynnette). The project will generate new knowledge about how to design effective instruction that helps students acquire well-integrated conceptual and procedural knowledge that is effective in real educational settings. This knowledge could lead to better, more conceptually-oriented instruction in algebra, and it has the potential to improve instruction in other STEM learning environments. The project will also create a new intelligent tutoring system for algebra that is much more effective than current systems. The system will be made available to teachers and schools free of charge.

por.por_cntn:
A persistent challenge in designing effective mathematics instruction is to foster deep learning of concepts and skills, as well as connections among them. Many instructional approaches are successful in helping students build procedural skills, but most have limited success in supporting students’ conceptual understanding or in fostering connections between procedural and conceptual understanding. Our project addressed this issue in a foundational mathematical domain, equation solving in middle school. Our aim was to develop an approach to algebra instruction that helps students acquire well-integrated knowledge of key concepts and problem-solving procedures about algebra equation solving.

 

To address this aim, we drew on the strengths of an effective educational technology, intelligent tutoring systems. We adapted and extended a previously developed, software-based intelligent tutoring system for equation solving, called Lynnette. We added activities that we expected would promote gains in conceptual and procedural understanding, including using diagrams to represent the equations and warm-up activities to activate prior knowledge. We also redesigned the intelligent tutoring system to be more engaging by including game-like features and by developing an interface that allowed students to “drag and drop” parts of equations, rather than type the equations into the interface. In laboratory studies and classroom studies, we evaluated whether the modified tutoring system promoted students’ acquisition of well-integrated conceptual and procedural knowledge. We also evaluated which aspects of the system were most critical for student learning. 

 

Our project yielded several key findings: (1) Students learned more with versions of the intelligent tutoring system that included worked examples and that elicited explanations from students for example steps than with versions that included only problem-solving activities. (2) Students transitioned more readily from informal to formal problem-solving strategies, with fewer errors, when they engaged with diagrams before they solved corresponding symbolic steps. (3) Students made fewer errors during the learning activities with sustained use of diagrams to illustrate steps in the equation-solving, compared to interleaved diagram use. (4) When students had the freedom to choose whether to use diagrams or not, proactive use of diagrams—that is, assessing whether to use diagrams based on the difficulty of the problem at hand—was associated with better learning. (5) Supporting students’ self-regulated choices about whether and when to use diagrams with metacognitive prompts promoted gains in both conceptual and procedural understanding. (6) Integrating game-like elements into the intelligent tutoring system (gamification) made students more engaged and made conceptual learning more effective. 

 

We have recently extended the system by incorporating additional game-like elements, and we collected new data in a classroom setting to evaluate the effects of gamification on students’ engagement and problem solving. This experiment also investigates how drag-and-drop interactions support learning of equation solving, separate from the other gamification elements. We have also conducted a study comparing the effects of student learning of our adapted tutor, called Colette, to an existing alternative learning system (Khan Academy). We are continuing to analyze data from these studies, and results will be forthcoming. These studies will establish the extent to which drag-and-drop interactions and gamification elements should be used in algebra learning software. 


This project has yielded new scientific knowledge about the role of diagrams in students’ learning in a foundational mathematical domain, and about how different ways of engaging with diagrams can contribute to the development of conceptual understanding and procedural skill. This project has also developed new intelligent tutoring systems for equation solving that are freely available on the Mathtutor website (http://equations.mathtutor.web.cmu.edu and http://gwynnette.mathtutor.web.cmu.edu). This project has yielded new scientific knowledge about basic cognitive and learning processes, including knowledge about how students engage with diagrams and about how students regulate their own learning. The insights we have gained about activities that support student learning are broadly applicable to the design of future adaptive learning systems, as well as other types of instructional and curricular materials for algebra and other mathematical content domains.
